qas.question: Who developed the first mnotor capable of being used for machinery?
What was the main problem with applying early electric motors to industry?

answers.text: the high cost of primary battery power

qas.question: What necessary technical development had yet to occur to make electric motors useful?
How fast did Sturgeon and Davenport's motors run?
Who developed the last motor capable of being used for machinery?

plausible_answers.text: high cost of primary battery power

qas.question: What wasn't the main problem with applying early electric motors to industry?
What necessary technical development always occurred to make electric motors useful?
How slow did Sturgeon and Davenport's motors run?

context: The first commutator DC electric motor capable of turning machinery was invented by the British scientist <a0_0><b5_0>William Sturgeon<b5_0/><a0_0/> in 1832. Following Sturgeon's work, a commutator-type direct-current electric motor made with the intention of commercial use was built by the American inventor <a1_0><b6_0>Thomas Davenport<b6_0/><a1_0/>, which he patented in 1837. The motors ran at up to <a4_0><b9_0>600 revolutions per minute<b9_0/><a4_0/>, and powered machine tools and a printing press. Due to <a2_0>the <b7_0>high cost of primary battery power<b7_0/><a2_0/>, the motors were commercially unsuccessful and Davenport went bankrupt. Several inventors followed Sturgeon in the development of DC motors but all encountered the same battery power cost issues. No <a3_0><b8_0>electricity distribution<b8_0/><a3_0/> had been developed at the time. Like Sturgeon's motor, there was no practical commercial market for these motors.
